qas.question: What do pigments do with the color green?
What are green paints and dyes usually made of?
What is the main chemical that causes emeralds to be green?
What is the source of the green color in malachite pigments?
What is the source of amazonite's color?

answers.text: small quantities of lead and water in the feldspar

qas.question: What is the name of minerals that emit green through their luminescence?
What is another name for amazonite?
What is the symbol for Copper?
What does Chromium oxide have trace amounts of?
What is the name of amazonite-based pigments?

context: Many <a1_0>minerals<a1_0/> provide pigments which have been used in green paints and dyes over the centuries. <b5_0>Pigments<b5_0/>, in this case, are minerals which <a0_0>reflect<a0_0/> the color green, rather that emitting it through luminescent or phosphorescent qualities. The large number of green pigments makes it impossible to mention them all. Among the more notable green minerals, however is the emerald, which is colored green by trace amounts of <a2_0>chromium<a2_0/> and sometimes <b8_0>vanadium<b8_0/>. Chromium(III) oxide (<b7_0>Cr2O3<b7_0/>), is called chrome green, also called <b6_0>viridian<b6_0/> or institutional green when used as a pigment. For many years, the source of amazonite's color was a mystery. Widely thought to have been due to copper because copper compounds often have blue and green colors, the blue-green color is likely to be derived from <a4_0>small quantities of lead and water in the feldspar<a4_0/>. <a3_0>Copper<a3_0/> is the source of the green color in <b9_0>malachite<b9_0/> pigments, chemically known as basic copper(II) carbonate.
